Award.AwardTitle: International Collaboration in Chemistry: Population Dynamics and Subdomain Stability of Folded Species in the Full-length Overhang Region of Human Telomeres
Award.AbstractNarration:
This International Collaboration in Chemistry award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division supports the work of Dr. Hanbin Mao from Kent State University to study telomeres, which are new DNA structures present at the end of chromosomes. The work is done in collaboration with Dr. Hiroshi Sugiyama of Kyoto University, Japan, who is funded by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science. The telomere regions of human chromosomes are involved in the processes of biological aging and tumor formation. Consequently the study of telomeres can inform and advance the quest for the treatment of age-related diseases and cancer. The goal of Dr. Mao's research is to elucidate the mechanochemical properties and population dynamics of the G-quadruplex species formed in a human telomeric DNA. To achieve this goal, Dr. Mao will use both existing physical methods as well as new methods developed in his lab for the study of one molecule at a time. The international character of the collaborative research offers a unique setting to train U.S. students. Visits of the research lab in Japan create the opportunity for the students to gain a global perspective and to acquire collaborative skills. High school students will participate in research in Dr. Mao's lab and will be prepared to participate in high school science competitions and scientific exhibitions.

Although of fundamental importance, the DNA G-quadruplex formed in the telomeres is difficult to investigate given the length of the telomeric region and the diversity of conformations it can adopt. This complex structural problem can be addressed using single-molecule methods newly developed in the labs of the investigators. At Kent State, optical tweezers will be used to dissect G-quadruplexes at sub-molecular level by mechanical unfolding through specific locations inside a G-quadruplex unit. On the other hand, by an approach analogous to the population dynamics in Biology, the population profiles of G-quadruplex species can be reconstructed after deconvolution of different structures. Evaluation of these population profiles in the presence of small molecules could enable the development of drugs, which interact with telomeric G-quadruplexes and thus interfere with various biological processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. This International Collaboration supports research by Professor Hanbin Mao at Kent State University and Professor Hiroshi Sugiyama of Kyoto University, who is funded by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS), to investigate properties of DNA structures, such as G-quadruplexes, located at the end of chromosomes (telomeres) or promoter regions of many genes.   These structures are involved in the modulation of gene expressions. Therefore, it is of high biological significance to elucidate the structures of these species, as well as population dynamics among various folding intermediates and misfolded structures.  In this project supported by NSF, the PI’s team has dissected the mechanical properties of telomeric G-quadruplex structures with and without ligands at the single molecular level using optical tweezers.  They found that mechanical stabilities of these structures are comparable to the stall forces of motor proteins, such as RNA polymerases, which describe the external force at which motor proteins stop their enzymatic activities. In addition, the research team revealed that different part of G-quadruplex structures has different mechanical stabilities.  This so called mechanical anisotropy is dramatically different when the G-quadruplexes are bound with small-molecule ligands.  With the same optical tweezers techniques, the research team has also elucidated relative populations of correctly-folded, misfolded, and various intermediates under different conditions including in the presence of small molecules that can bind to these structures. These discoveries offer new insights to understand the modulation effects of G-quadruplex structures on the gene expression.  They also provide guidelines to design ligands that can bind more tightly to G-quadruplex from mechanical perspective, or ligands that can act more efficiently from the angle of mechanical interaction with motor proteins.

Broader Impact. This NSF grant has allowed us to train nine high school students, Benjamin Wales-McGrath, Maggie Paul, Serena Kaplan, Jia Wei, Andrew Tian, Larry Phillips, Rebecca Stayer, Mira Scarnecchia, and Alva Mao; five college students, Medelyn Kist, Christian Beneze Katia Ascencio, Athena Guo, and Mason McCool; and six graduate students, Jibin Abraham Punnoose, Sagun Jonchhe, Shankar Pandey, Deepak Karna, Sangeetha Selvam, and Prakash Shrestha, at Kent State University.  These students frequently interacted with Professor Hiroshi Sugiyama and his graduate students in Kyoto University.  In fact, Prakash spent one month at Hiroshi Sugiyama’s lab in September of 2015, learning AFM imaging on DNA structures.  As a part of international collaboration, we also hosted graduate students, Yusuke Kawamoto and Yue Li from Japan to facilitate them to perform experiments using optical tweezers in our lab. The international collaboration provided invaluable experiences to the young scientists at Kent State University.  In addition, the involvement of undergraduate and high school students in the project allowed to allure young people to the STEM fields.  For example, Katia Ascencio in Los Angeles Harbor College has strengthened her determination to be a scientist in the future, whereas high-school student Jia Wei became a college student in Cornell University, working toward a scientific BA degree.
